candidates.definition: active market participation through buying, selling, or speculating with financial instruments or assets

positive_examples: She bought 100 shares of Apple stock this morning
The trader sold his Bitcoin holdings before the market closed
He made a short sale on Tesla stock, betting the price would fall
The vending machine accepted payment for the snacks
They invested their savings in a diversified portfolio
She placed a bet on the horse race at 5-to-1 odds
negative_examples: The bank processed his loan application
She transferred money to her savings account
The company paid dividends to shareholders
He deposited his paycheck into checking
They received an insurance payout for the accident
The mortgage payment was automatically deducted
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: FinancialTransfer, Payment, Lending, InsuranceTransaction

candidates.definition: Movement of money between accounts, institutions, or parties without buying/selling securities

positive_examples: I deposited my paycheck into my savings account this morning
She withdrew $200 from the ATM for grocery shopping
The company transferred funds from checking to their investment account
He sent a wire transfer to his daughter studying abroad
They rolled over their 401k to a new employer's plan
The automatic payment for utilities was processed today
negative_examples: She bought 100 shares of Apple stock through her broker
The company issued new bonds to raise capital
He sold his cryptocurrency holdings for a profit
The bank charged a $5 service fee for account maintenance
They applied for a mortgage loan to buy a house
The insurance company paid out a claim after the accident
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: SecurityTrading, LoanTransaction, InsuranceClaim, BankingFees

candidates.definition: Instructions to buy, sell, or cancel transactions in financial markets or securities trading

positive_examples: The trader placed a buy order for 100 shares of Apple stock
Her broker filled the sell order at the market price
He cancelled his pending order before the market closed
The limit order was executed when the stock hit $50
She modified her stop-loss order to protect her gains
The day trader's order was partially filled during morning volatility
negative_examples: The company completed its merger with the competitor
He transferred money from his checking to savings account
She received her quarterly dividend payment
The bank approved his mortgage loan application
They split the restaurant bill three ways
The insurance claim was processed successfully
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: PaymentProcessing, AccountTransfers, LoanTransactions, DividendPayments

candidates.definition: Trading activities involving option contracts that give the right to buy or sell assets at specified prices.

positive_examples: The investor exercised her call options to purchase 100 shares at the strike price.
He implemented a covered call strategy to generate additional income from his stock holdings.
She decided to exercise her put options before expiration to lock in profits.
The trader used a butterfly spread strategy combining multiple option contracts.
After the stock price rose above $50, he exercised his call options immediately.
The portfolio manager employed a protective put strategy to hedge against market downturns.
negative_examples: The company issued new shares through a public stock offering.
She bought 200 shares of Microsoft on the open market.
The bond trader purchased $10,000 in corporate bonds at par value.
He sold his entire position in Apple stock for a capital gain.
The mutual fund manager rebalanced the portfolio by selling tech stocks.
They completed the merger by exchanging shares at the agreed ratio.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: StockTrading, BondTransaction, CommodityTrading, ForexTransaction, IPOActivity

candidates.definition: Financial obligations, liabilities, and debt-related transactions including fees, defaults, restructuring, and liquidation.

positive_examples: The company defaulted on its corporate bonds last quarter.
They're refinancing their mortgage to get a lower interest rate.
The bank charged a $25 overdraft fee on my account.
The startup had to liquidate its assets to pay creditors.
She missed three consecutive loan payments and faces foreclosure.
The credit card company is restructuring my payment plan.
negative_examples: I bought 100 shares of Apple stock this morning.
The merger between the two companies was announced today.
She deposited her paycheck into her savings account.
The dividend payment will be issued next month.
He sold his cryptocurrency holdings for a profit.
The company issued new bonds to raise capital.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: StockTrading, CorporateMergers, BankingServices, InvestmentManagement, CurrencyExchange

candidates.definition: Financial activities and transactions involving corporate stock ownership, trading, or portfolio management.

positive_examples: Apple's stock split gave shareholders twice as many shares at half the price.
The investment advisor recommended allocating 60% of the portfolio to stocks and 40% to bonds.
Tesla's stock price surged after the quarterly earnings report exceeded expectations.
She decided to diversify her investments by buying stocks in different sectors.
The company announced a 2-for-1 stock split to make shares more accessible to retail investors.
His asset allocation strategy focuses heavily on growth stocks and emerging markets.
negative_examples: The bank approved her mortgage application for the new house purchase.
He paid for groceries using his credit card at the checkout.
The company issued bonds to raise capital for expansion.
She withdrew cash from the ATM to pay for parking.
The insurance claim was processed within two business days.
He transferred money from checking to savings to earn higher interest.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: BondTransactions, CurrencyExchange, BankingServices, InsuranceTransactions

candidates.definition: Activities related to managing, accessing, or modifying financial accounts and their data

positive_examples: She opened a new savings account at the local bank yesterday
The company decided to close their unused checking account to reduce fees
He has full control over his investment account and can make trades anytime
I use my credit card account regularly for online purchases
The bank updated my account information after I moved to a new address
They're switching who has access to the joint account after the divorce
negative_examples: The stock price increased by 15% after the earnings announcement
She bought 100 shares of Apple stock through her broker
The company issued new bonds to raise capital for expansion
He sold his cryptocurrency holdings before the market crashed
The mutual fund performed well compared to the market index
They're considering investing in real estate as a hedge against inflation
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: StockTrading, BondTransactions, CommodityTrading, InvestmentDecisions
